sn1.34:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
sn1.34:1.2: Then, late at night, several glorious deities of the Satullapa Group, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.
sn1.34:1.3: Standing to one side, one deity recited this verse in the Buddha’s presence:
sn1.34:2.1: “Among humans there are no sensual pleasures that are permanent.
sn1.34:2.2: Here there are sensuous things, bound to which,
sn1.34:2.3: drunk on which, there’s no coming back.
sn1.34:2.4: That person doesn’t return here from Death’s domain.”
sn1.34:3.1: “Misery is born of desire; suffering is born of desire;
sn1.34:3.2: when desire is removed, misery is removed;
sn1.34:3.3: when misery is removed, suffering is removed.”
sn1.34:4.1: “The world’s pretty things aren’t sensual pleasures.
sn1.34:4.2: Greedy intention is a person’s sensual pleasure.
sn1.34:4.3: The world’s pretty things stay just as they are,
sn1.34:4.4: but a wise one removes desire for them.
sn1.34:5.1: Give up anger, get rid of conceit,
sn1.34:5.2: and get past all the fetters.
sn1.34:5.3: Sufferings don’t torment the one who has nothing,
sn1.34:5.4: not clinging to name and form.
sn1.34:6.2: craving for name and form is cut off right here.
sn1.34:6.3: They’ve cut the ties, untroubled, with no need for hope.
sn1.34:6.4: Though gods and humans search for them
sn1.34:6.5: in this world and the world beyond, they never find them,
sn1.34:6.6: not in heaven nor in any abode.”
sn1.34:7.1: “If neither gods nor humans see one freed in this way,”
sn1.34:7.3: “in this world or the world beyond,
sn1.34:7.4: are those who revere that supreme person,
sn1.34:7.5: who lives for the good of mankind, also worthy of praise?”
sn1.34:8.1: “The mendicants who revere one freed in this way,”
sn1.34:8.4: But having understood the teaching and given up doubt,
sn1.34:8.5: those mendicants can escape their chains.”
